AE.Display.Animation.Animation2d#

class AE.Display.Animation.Animation2d(parent=None, size=None, sceneLimits=None, disp_boundaries=True, disp_time=False, dt=None)#

Bases: object

2D Animation

Base class for two-dimensional animations.

The Animation2d.Qview attribute is a QGraphicsView and can thus be used directly as a QWidget in any Qt application. For rapid display, the companion class Window allows to easily create a new window for the animation.

Note

Two times are at play in an animation: the display time, whose increments are approximately the inverse of the Animation2d.fps attribute, and the animation time, which is a virtual quantity unrelated to the actual time. This way, slow motion or fast-forward animations can be displayed. The Animation2d.dt attibute controls the increment of animation time between two display updates.

item#

All items in the scene.

Type:

{item subclass}

sceneLimits#

Limits of the scene.

Type:

{‘x’, ‘y’, ‘width’, ‘height’}

margin#

Margin around the scene (pix).

Type:

float

timeHeight#

Position of the time display relative to the top of the scene (pix).

Type:

float

fps#

Display framerate (1/s). Default is 25.

Type:

float

t#

Current animation time (s).

Type:

float

dt#

Animation time increment (s) between two updates.

Type:

float

disp_time#

If true, the animation time is overlaid to the animation.

Type:

bool

disp_boundaries#

If true, a thin grey rectanle is overlaid to indicate the boundaries.

Type:

bool

parent#

If not None (default), a simple window containing the animation is created.

Type:

QWidget or Window

Qscene#

QGraphicsScene containing the elements.

Type:

QGraphicsScene

Qview#

QGraphicsView widget representing the scene.

Type:

QGraphicsView

timer#

Timer storing the display time since the animation start.

Type:

QElapsedTimer

Qtimer#

Timer managing the display updates.

Type:

QTimer

__init__(parent=None, size=None, sceneLimits=None, disp_boundaries=True, disp_time=False, dt=None)#

Animation constructor

Defines all the attributes of the animation, especially the QGraphicsScene and QGraphicsView necessary for rendering.

Parameters:

  • parent (Qwidget or Window) – Parent container. It can be a QWidget or a Window object. If not set, a new Window object is created and assigned as a parent.

  • size (float) – Height of the QGraphicsView.

  • sceneLimits ([[float,float],[float,float]]) – Limits of the scene to display. The first element sets the x-limits and the second the y-limits. Default is [[0,1],[0,1]].

  • disp_boundaries (bool) – If true, a thin grey rectanle is overlaid to indicate the boundaries.

  • disp_time (bool) – If true, the animation time is overlaid to the animation.

  • dt (float) – Animation time increment (s) between two updates. Default: 0.04.

Methods

__init__([parent, size, sceneLimits, ...])

Animation constructor

add(type, name, **kwargs)

Add an item to the scene.

change(type, item)

Change notification

show()

Display animation window

Update animation state
add(type, name, **kwargs)#

Add an item to the scene.

Parameters:

item (item subclass) – The item to add.

change(type, item)#

Change notification

This method is triggered whenever an item is changed. It does nothing and has to be reimplemented in subclasses.

Note

To catch motion the item has to be declared as movable, which is not the default.

Parameters:

  • type (str) – Type of change (move).

  • item (item subclass) – The changed item.

show()#

Display animation window

If the animation’s parent is a Window object, the Window.show() method is called. Otherwise nothing is done.

startAnimation()#

Start the animation

Trigs the animation Animation.Qtimer QTimer, which starts the animation.

update()#

Update animation state

Update the animation time Animation.t. Subclass this method to implement the animation, e.g. moving elements or changing color.
